text: The house is crammed with GUESTS OF ALL AGES. Birthday decorations announce the occasion. We move through the party behind AGNES, the lady of the house, the woman behind the hands from the opening montag She's carrying a tray, offering appetizers. The occasional GUEST kisses Agnes on the cheek or says "t you" but mostly people just take a piece off the tray wit paying much attention to her. She doesn’t mind it at all. She’s happy unseen. LAUGHTER AND CHATTER ALL AROUND. Agnes glides by LOUIE, her husband, who’s sitting on the couch with a FEW FRIENDS, shooting the breeze. Louie palm few appetizers and passes them around to his pals.
Thanks, babe. You’re the best. RONNIE, Louie’s close friend, takes a bite.
Amazing, Agnes. Really. Always. (CONTINUED )
Agnes nods and moves down the hallway into the den where TEENAGE BOYS are sitting around with her son GABE (17), watching a YouTube video and laughing their heads off.
Hey Mom, more salami. Agnes smiles and nods, turns on her heels, heading back t the kitchen.
A small crucifix hangs in the window above Agnes who is n expertly chopping up more salami and arranging the slices a large plate.

location: LIVING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE'S HOUSE

text: Agnes is moving through the crowded living room with the plate of salami when Louie and his Friends burst out laughing. She jumps just as Louie's plate slides off his and shatters into a dozen pieces on the floor. Ronnie and others all hoot. They’ve been drinking.
Careful. I'll be right there. Don’t move. Agnes hurries to the hallway into the den to give Gabe th salami plate.
Thanks.

location: LIVING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE'S HOUSE

text: Agnes enters with a broom and a dust pan. She kneels next Louie and sweeps up the pieces.
Don’t worry about it. Seriously. He gives her a kiss. AGNES (CONT’D) Are you having fun?
Great time.
I’m glad. (CONTINUED )
We're going to go up front and smoke.
Really?
Just one. I swear.
I’1l call you for cake.
Is Ziggy around?
He’s around. Somewhere.
Tell him to come join us. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Agnes washes the broken pieces of Louie’s plate. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT

Agnes gets glue out of the kitchen drawer. Spreads all th pieces of Louie’s broken plate out on the counter and attempts to fit them together. ESZTER, Agnes’ sister-in-law, comes in. She gives Agnes a baffled look.
Do you need a hand?
What? Oh. No. I’m-- (re: plate) I’m missing a piece. It’s tiny. I’ll never find it.
There’s no shame in asking for help, you know. You don’t have to do everything.
I know. I know. But-- I like doing everything. I don’t need any help. Thank you.  10

location: LIVING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE'S HOUSE

text: Louie and his friends walk back into the house to find Ag crawling around on her knees looking for the tiny missing piece.
What's going on?
There's a piece missing. From the plate. I don’t want anyone to step on--
Come on, Agnes. Stand up! She ignores him and continues to look. He puts a hand on shoulder.
Hey. Later, okay? Not tonight. Please. It’s not like anyone ever walks around here barefoot. She stands, disappointed, mission aborted.
You're so cute. Their oldest son, ZIGGY (19), scrutinizes them from acros the room.
Agnes pulls the frosted cake out of the refrigerator. She sticks candles in the cake and looks at it for a long beat.

location: DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE'S HOUSE

text: Holding the cake with the lit candles, Agnes walks out of kitchen into the dining room. ALL THE PARTY GUESTS gather

(singing loudly) Happy birthday to you, happy birthday to you, happy birthday-- dear... Agnes, happy birthday to you. Agnes sets the cake down on the dining room table and loo at it, pleased, her face glowing in the candlelight. This indeed HER birthday party. This is her world. Her life. S blows out the candles. (CONTINUED )
Speech! Speech! EVERYONE LAUGHS. They know Agnes well enough to get the j Agnes swallows hard. Clearly, she’s uncomfortable with ev hint of attention.
(whispering) Thank you, everyone. Ziggy inches closer.
Speak up, ma!
Oh, leave the woman alone, will you? Agnes clears her throat, about to speak. Everyone quiets down.
Who wants cake?
Humming to herself, Agnes puts the last of the party dish away. The house is hers again; the guests gone, her men asleep upstairs. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 12

Agnes sits down at the kitchen table, exhausted. She pour herself a large glass of red wine. Suddenly, she remember something that sends her out of the room excitedly. INT. DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 13
Agnes is halfway through unwrapping her presents. They’ r 1 pretty generic: a vase, a wooden ladle, a book
(reading book title) Aging with Grace: What the Nun Study Teaches Us About Leading Longer, Healthier, and More Meaningful Lives. She rolls her eyes.
Oh, Zig. (CONTINUED )

She puts the book away. Opens and reads a series of Hallm cards. Opens a small box and finds an iPhone inside. Stares at i if it came from the future. Puts it down with little interest. Then she unwraps a long, rectangular present. It's a Ravensburger puzzle, 1500 pieces. A beautiful contemporar map of the world. Agnes studies the puzzle, then sets it aside.

Agnes crawls into bed next to Louie who is SNORING LOUDLY She lies there awake for a while. An old ALARM CLOCK TICKS on the night table on Louie’s si of the bed. Agnes listens to the TICKING. Louie groans and turns onto his side, putting his arm around her. The SNORING stops. Agnes closes her eyes, relieved. A few seconds later, the SNORING starts up again. But she already asleep.

head_text.subj: THE SNORING KEEPS GOING. THE CLOCK TICKS.

text: Card: PUZZLE
Burning street lights turn off neighborhood by neighborho as night succumbs. WE HEAR THE CLOCK TICKING. FOLLOWED BY AGNES’S WHISPERS,
ACCOMPANIED BY LOUIE’S SNORING.

Day breaks over the working-class neighborhood. Modest ho line the residential streets, most darkened, but some alr busy with early morning rituals. AGNES'S WHISPERS CONTINUE. THE TICKING CLOCK KEEPS TIME. LOUIE’S SNORING KEEPS GOING. (CONTINUED )
We move closer to a little side street to find Agnes and Louie’s simple house with its well-kept front lawn.

Bars of sunlight streak the window glass, filtering into dimness of the room. Agnes is wide awake with her eyes closed, WHISPERING. Behind her, Louie is asleep on his back, mouth open, SNOR As we glide closer to her we can make out Agnes's words, from prayers:

(whispering to herself) Eleven, ten, nine, eight, seven, six, five, four, three, two, one. She opens her eyes, expecting... something. Nothing happe She listens to the CLOCK TICKING. Quickly closes her eyes again. It’s a game of sorts. AGNES (CONT’D) (whispering to herself) Seven, six, five, four, three, two, one. Agnes opens her eyes. Nothing. She’s clearly disappointed Louie lets out a NASALLY SNORE. She giggles. She closes h eyes again in anticipation. AGNES (CONT’D) (whispering to herself) Five, four, three, two, one. Now. THE ALARM BELL RINGS. She opens her eyes and smiles to herself in victory. Sits up in bed. Leans over Louie and turns the ALARM BELL OFF. Louie continues to sleep. Agnes shakes him. AGNES (CONT’D) Lou. Honey. Louie.
(groggy) What?
Time to get up.
What? (CONTINUED )
It’s a new day. He turns over on his side, his back to her. AGNES (CONT’D) (whispering to herself) Five more minutes. (to Louie) Honey, time to get up.
Five more minutes.
(whispering to herself) Please. Please. 18 INT. GABE’S BEDROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - MORNING
Lights on! In the TV monitor hooked up to an XBox, we see Agnes's reflection as she shuffles in to wake up her youn son Gabe. She touches his shoulder tenderly.
Five more minutes, Mom.

Agnes walks down the corridor, HUMMING TO HERSELF, and KN on a bedroom door. No response. She KNOCKS AGAIN. 20 INT. ZIGGY’S BEDROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - MORNIN Lights on! Ziggy, bare-chested and sporting a botched tat buries himself under the covers. In the large mirror, we Agnes move in.
Ten more minutes, Mom. I swear. Agnes smiles to herself as she watches Ziggy go back to sleep. She starts picking up dirty clothes off the floor desk.
Agnes walks down the stairs when LOUD HIP HOP EXPLODES FR GABE’S ROOM. Agnes stops on the stairs, turns and looks up to calmly watch: (CONTINUED )
Louie storming out of the bathroom, shaving cream hanging from his chin, razor in hand. He KNOCKS on Gabe’s door.
Turn that off, goddamnit! Every morning the same crap. The HIP HOP MUSIC IS LOWERED. Louie then catches Agnes's watchful eye. He shrugs innocently at her. She smiles at
Manchego omelette? He beams at the suggestion.
Be down in a minute.
Agnes inspects her hands by holding them up to the sunlig blasting the glass. THE SOUND OF ZIGGY LAUGHING REVERBERATES FROM UPSTAIRS.

Stop. Gabe. Stop. I’m serious. I’m gonna pee my pants. Agnes GRINDS COFFEE BEANS IN THE GRINDER. She walks over to get a coffee mug when her gaze falls on framed photo of an OLDER MAN standing with YOUNG AGNES in very same kitchen. Tears start streaming down her face. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - MORNING 23
Agnes is making omelettes and sausages while Louie and Zi chat over coffee; both men are wearing clean mechanics coveralls. Gabe is hunched over Agnes’s new iPhone.
(to Ziggy) Hey, Mom, what kind of apps Which grit do you use_when do you want? you're doing the final sanding?
(to Louie) I don’t want apps. I don’t Are you really quizzing me want that phone. Mine’s over breakfast? perfectly fine. You take it. (CONTINUED )
(to Ziggy) | I'm not quizzing you. I saw you using a 1200 grit the other day and that's never gonna work.
I don't want to talk about this at home, dad. I need a break. 10. 23
(to Agnes) How about the weather channel?
I have a radio and a window. I know when it’s going to rain.
You'll get a break once you (to Agnes do everything right, Zig. I put my number and Ziggy 's and Dad's on speed dial. Who else do you want?

Mom, do you need any help cooking? Agnes shakes her head, then puts eggs and sausages on a p and hands it to Gabe. ZIGGY (CONT’D) GABE (to Louie) (to Agnes) Fine. What? I should've used What about Ezster? And the 400? Church ladies?
That or 600. (to Gabe) I don't _know why I wouldn't just call them from the home phone. Gabe throws up his hands, exasperated.
Will someone please explain to my mother why she has to stop living in the 20th century?
Are you even gonna use it, Mom?.
I guess I might use it like my old phone. For emergencies.
Forget it!
I don’t like all this technology. Is that really so crazy? (CONTINUED )
Yes. Absolutely. A hundred percent.
Leave your mother alone. She doesn't like gadgets.
Then why did we get it for her?
Because it’s a thoughtful gift.
Not if she never uses it. (to Agnes) Just try it. Google something. Recipes. Bible study. Whatever. Everything in the world is inside this one device.
No. It's like carrying a little robot in your purse. A little alien robot friend. I don’t need it.
Clearly it doesn’t need you either. Louie slaps Gabe’s shoulder. Agnes serves Louie and Ziggy Gabe takes a series of pictures of Agnes with her iPhone:

We move through the series of iPhone photos of Agnes, goi through a range of expressions flickering across her face affection, sadness, exhaustion, weariness, quiet judgment and, finally Agnes’s hand blocking the phone.

Enough. You're all gonna be late. INT. FRONT PORCH. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 25 Agnes sits alone on the front porch, delighting in a piec her birthday cake, watching the daylight moon in the sky. Every bite is a calm celebration. INT. DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 26
Agnes walks back into the house and spots the puzzle box, still sitting in its plastic wrapping on the table with t other gifts. (CONTINUED )
She moves closer to the table. Shuts her eyes and randoml places her finger on the puzzle map picture on the box to She opens her eyes, looks at what she’s pointed to:

(disappointed) Belgium! She makes a face and walks into the kitchen. We stay in t dining room. Hear the SINK WATER TURN ON. FOLLOWED BY THE RADIO, THE DIAL MOVING, LANDING ON CLASSICAL MUSIC. Suddenly, she marches back in, determined. Picks the puzz box up and quickly, as if forcing herself against her bet judgement, rips off the plastic wrapping and opens the bo She takes out the sheet of paper with instructions on it puts her hand in the loose pile of puzzle pieces, letting them sift through her fingers. It's like she's running he hand through sand or water; there's something sensual abo it. A second later, she dumps the puzzle pieces onto the tabl and sits down. Starts turning pieces over quickly. INT. DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - AFTERNOON 27 POLKA MUSIC ON THE RADIO, a different program. Agnes hasn moved from her seat in hours. She’s fitting the last few pieces of the puzzle into place, rubbing her tired eyes. Suddenly she notices the time and leaps from her seat. INT. KITCHEN SIDE ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - AFTERNO
Agnes quickly puts in a load of laundry.

Agnes drives through the streets of West Bridgeport. She’ a hurry but she steers carefully, slow and measured, with little confidence, foot jumping back and forth from gas p to brake, far from oblivious to the tension of the HONKS behind her.
I’m trying. I know. I’m trying.
(CONTINUED )

--Agnes moves quickly up and down the brightly lit aisles the supermarket. --She chooses one cereal, then quickly looks at its ingredients, then puts it back on the shelf, then picks another and throws it in her cart, then reconsiders, puts back and picks the original cereal... --She stands at the deli counter watching impatiently whi PIMPLY ADOLESCENT BOY endlessly slices ham for her... --She peers through the frosted windows of the frozen foo aisle... --She hurries down the fruit aisle, pushing her cart like race car driver. -She stuffs cucumbers into a plastic bag in the produce section... -She bags her groceries one by one just as soon as a particularly slow GROCERY CLERK scans them at the registe one after another. BEEP. BEEP. BEEP. BEEP. BEEP. BEEP. BE It’s excruciating for her to wait, but she keeps the same polite, patient, slightly quizzical expression on her fac The Grocery Clerk finishes. Agnes swipes her charge card. Punches in the number. The sound of a receipt printing.
All set.
Thank you. She grabs her bag and rushes off. Comes back and gets her receipt.
Agnes drives back home through the streets of West Bridgeport. There’s more traffic than earlier. It’s rush hour. She checks the dashboard clock. HONKS THE HORN when light turns green.

INT. KITCHEN SIDE ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - EVENING Agnes moves the wet laundry to the dryer.  34 35 14. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - EVENING 34 Agnes runs over to the sink, fills a pot with boiling wat and grabs a jar of tomato sauce from the cupboard. She he the FRONT DOOR OPEN AND SHUT. A beat later, Gabe walks in
Hey. He gives her a kiss on the cheek.
Hi, sweety. How was your day?
Kind of whatever. Chess club was cool. Hockey was canceled; Coach Wilson got bad diarrhea. (laughing) How was your day?
Busy. Pretty busy.
Any emergencies?

None. Thank God. He laughs and grabs an apple off the table. INT. DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 35 Wearing dirty coveralls, Ziggy walks in to set up the tab He checks out the finished puzzle.
Hey, Mom, what do I do with this thing on--? Agnes runs in, wiping her hands in a kitchen towel.
Sorry. She breaks the puzzle up.
No, don’t! Too late. She throws puzzle pieces into the box.
That’s 1500 pieces, Mom. She shrugs. Louie comes down the stairs post-shower. (CONTINUED )
What’s going on?
Nothing. Mom just--
Dinner is almost ready.
(to Ziggy) You're not going to change?
Mom asked me to set the table.
In these filthy clothes?
It’s okay. I’1l do it.
35 36 Agnes is lying in bed, struggling to make out the small p of the puzzle instructions with an old magnifying glass. Louie is changing into his pajamas.
He's lazy. He looks at her, she’s trying to read. LOUIE (CONT’D) Agnes, are you listening?
Shhh. Lower your voice.
What are you reading there?
Puzzle instructions.
You put the pieces together until you run out, what other instructions do you need? ___ AGNES ; Suggestions. Strategies. It doesn’t matter. She puts the paper away. (CONTINUED )
You're so cute. (pause) Puzzles are for children, Agnes.
I don't think he's lazy.

He just sits there until I ask him to do something. He'll do whatever I tell him but he won't take any initiative. All day long. 16. 36 Louie faces her in his pajama bottoms, shirtless. Agnes e him, her expression betraying worry.
What?
Huh? LOUIE ; You were looking at me with some kind of-- some kind of look in your eyes.
No I wasn’t.
I know you, Agnes.
There was no look--
Just say it.
There was no look.
I turned down a doughnut today. Okay? A jelly doughnut! Do you know how hard that was for me?
You should be very proud of yourself.
I am. I’m smoking a lot less. For you. For us. Cholesterol is a genetic thing. It’s not my fault... He turns the lights off and gets in bed, putting his arm around her. (CONTINUED )

I just don’t want to lose you. 1 hi LOUIE au in thet, pray a) me! (pause) Is iP hot in here? She sighs, gets up and opens a crack in the window. Stops staring out at: Ziggy, smoking a cigarette outside, looking through messa on his phone, a picture of youthful loneliness. She gets in bed.
Agnes steers her car into the church parking lot.

head_text.subj: THE ORGAN IS BEING TUNED, WAY TOO LOUD AND SCREECHY.

text: Brightly colored light streams through the giant stained glass windows. Agnes walks through the entrance, waves to THE SHORT WOMA mopping the floors and crosses to a side door where a han written sign reads: ST. STEPHENS LADIES GUILD MEETING. She opens the door and walks down the stairs.

location: BASEMENT. ST. STEPHENS CHURCH. BRIDGEPORT, CT

text: Children's Sunday School drawings decorate every inch of every wall. The meeting is in progress: HOUSEWIVES (30s-70s) sit ina circle of chairs, Agnes and Ezster amongst them. FANNY, 5 overly made-up, is the Ladies Guild leader.

Well, Lent starts in five days. Since we're no longer doing the soup kitchen, we need to start organizing a food drive. The women start passing around a sign-up sheet. Agnes's attention is on the children’s drawings: the broken lines the bright colors, the naive settings - she’s mesmerized.
Is it true Father Kutash is only going to do confession once a month now? (CONTINUED )
No one shows up. There's nothing we can do about it. The sign-up sheet gets to Agnes and she takes the pen and paper.

(to herself, loudly) I guess we'll just pack our sins into neat monthly portions. Everyone stares at her. She turns beet red. Quickly signs name. AGNES (CONT’D) (passing the sheet) I’m sorry. It was a joke. I didn’t realize I was speaking out loud.

Church Ladies exit the building and head to their cars. Agnes is sitting in her parked car, laughing to herself a CLASSICAL MUSIC PLAYS ON THE RADIO. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY Al Agnes dumps her bags down on the counter. Then she walks to the phone and dials.

Aunt Emily. It's Agnes. We missed you at the party. How are you? I heard. Completely broken? Which part? The fifth what? Fifth metatarsal? I don’t know what that is. I'm so sorry. Good, good. No. It’s just-- I have a question. The present you sent me with Vlad. The puzzle. Yeah. No, it’s very nice. Where did you buy it? Agnes grabs a pencil and a note pad while she listens, an scrawls something down.

Uh-huh. Uh-huh. (disappointed) Oh, that’s too bad. No. I haven’t been to New York in years. I couldn’t ask Vlad. Online? Louie says we shouldn't give credit card numbers online. I guess sometimes it’s better to be paranoid. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

His friend Ronnie had his identity stolen. His life was hell for nine months. Anyway, thanks. All the best. Bye bye. She hangs up. Looks down at the note pad, where she has written: ‘Thompson and 3rd street.’ INT. DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 42 Agnes stares at the assembled world map puzzle on the tab with a great deal of pride. She did it again! And in half time. She looks at the world. The world looks back at her. Then starts taking it apart. INT. DEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 43

Agnes has a stack of blank Hallmark invitations and envel on the table, along with stamps and extra pens. She uses red pen to inscribe something in one card. Then puts the away. Takes another, repeats. Adds it to the pile.
INT. GABE'S ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 45

Agnes searches through Gabe's closet. A small box of cond falls out from behind a pile of old clothes and onto the ground. Agnes stares at it, then puts it back. INT. BASEMENT. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 46 A dim light turns on to reveal taxidermied fish of every possible size, mounted on the wall and displayed on stand all around. There are also stacks of fishing poles and bo of fly-fishing supplies. Agnes goes into a corner of the basement and rummages thr boxes and toys, until:

Tada! She finds a very old children’s puzzle set: The Incredibl Hulk. Only a hundred pieces. She immediately sits down on basement floor, empties out the box and starts assembling pieces. She’s becoming an addict.  47 20. INT. DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 47

The family around the table, plus NICKI, 17, Gabe’s girlfriend. Agnes comes in from the kitchen with a gorgeous stuffed chicken dish she adds to a salad assembled in the likenes a fish. There’s homemade bread along with other elaborate dishes on the table.
The chicken is stuffed with potatoes and-
Mom! Nicki!
(to Nicki) I thought you just didn't eat red meat.
I'm vegan. GABE . We went through this already, Mom.
So you never ever eat chicken?
(to, Nicki) It's like she’s hoping you'll forget. It’s so embarrassing.
I should have made fish. I’m sorry.
She doesn’t eat any animals, Mom.
But she has to have protein, she’s still growing.
Mom, don’t say dumb shit like that--
Hey. Enough. Okay.
(to Nicki) The way we were raised, everything had to come with meat. I’m sorry. (CONTINUED )
It's fine. I can eat the salad. And bread. I’m fine. Nicki takes the salad, stirs it up with salad tongs and serves herself. Agnes watches confused.
(to Nicki) Have you always been this way?
Nicki’s also a Buddhist.
That sounds interesting.
You know, I have no idea what that really means. Buddhist. I always hear people talking about Buddhism and celebrities and nobody says what it is.
It's like-- Like the root of all suffering is our desire not to suffer. Intrigued by this strange young woman, Agnes stares, forgetting the food.
So we have to give up on the idea of being happy Ziggy eats quietly. Gabe’s practically glowing.
(impressed) You don't care about being happy?
I try not to think that way. Happiness is an illusion. Agnes serves herself some chicken.
Are your parents unhappy? Ziggy cracks up. Nicki stares, surprised.
Mom!
I mean, like Buddhist? Did they raise you this way? (CONTINUED )
God. No. They’re stuck in the past.
Isn't Buddhism also from the past?

No. Yeah. I mean they’re more conventional Western thinkers. When they bother to think. That’s what I mean. Louie laughs, he likes Nicki’s spirit. Agnes gives hima look, she’s not amused. Ziggy clocks his mother’s anguish a GABE Nicki won't even-- She doesn't even kill mosquitoes.

I read something about this kid who drowned in a river because a Buddhist monk was the only one watching him and if you're a Buddhist you're not supposed to try to save people's lives. Like you're not supposed to interfere with their path.
What?!
That doesn't sound true.
Why can't Buddhists save lives?
Where did you read that?
It was an article. It was a real article on like the Huffington Post or something.
Um, yeah, that's not Buddhism. Buddhism respects life. It just has a different approach to death and suffering.
That monk should be shot.
Dad! /Louie!
Are you volunteering, Dad? (CONTINUED )
No. He’s right. I mean. Metaphorically. An awkward pause among the less righteous.
Yeah. Metaphorically. I get it. He locks eyes with Agnes who stares daggers at him. It’s if he’s betrayed her somehow.
How’s your chicken, Louie?
It’s good. He notices Nicki looking at him.
A little dry. But good. Agnes stands up alarmed.
There’s gravy. EXT. BACKYARD. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - MORNING B48
Daylight. All is calm and quiet. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - MORNING 48
Agnes makes coffee. Ziggy, looking groggy, comes in and, without saying a word, takes the eggs out of the fridge a starts breaking them into a bowl. He likes to help.
Good morning.
What’s good about it?

Agnes waits on the mostly empty train platform, shivering slightly. A FEW BUSINESS MEN in suits, late for work or working late, mill about, looking at their iPhones and iP ONE is shuffling through his iPod. Agnes eyes the i’S.
Agnes sits in the back of the moving train and looks out window as Bridgeport flies by. Trees turn the outside wor into a green blur. The TRAIN CONDUCTOR comes by.
A ticket to Grand Central please.
That's nineteen dollars. Agnes balks. Stares horrified.
How much?
Nineteen.
I thought it was eight.
Are you an active duty member of the United States armed forces, or disabled or a senior?
No. None of those things.
It’s nineteen dollars one way, off- peak hours when you purchase tickets on board. Next time buy it at the station. It’s cheaper. You could get a ten trip or a weekly.
That's okay. I don’t really think they'll be a next time. She hands him a twenty.
One way?
I'll buy the return in Grand Central.
Agnes stands in the middle of Grand Central's atrium, sta up at the golden constellations on the ceiling. (CONTINUED )
HUNDREDS OF PEOPLE jostle past her, some almost knocking over. But she can't stop staring.

Agnes sits in the back of a yellow cab, staring out the window at the Big Bad Apple, like a tourist, moving slowl through Manhattan traffic. From time to time she looks at the meter with worry as th fare climbs mercilessly. When it gets to ten dollars, she leans forward toward THE DRIVER.
Could you stop please? I’1l walk. I’m sorry.
Agnes crosses Washington Square taking in the fountain an the diverse crowds of STUDENTS, STREET MUSICIANS, TOURIST and THE HOMELESS.
Agnes stops in front of a tiny shop window filled with puzzles on display: PUZZLEMANIA. The look in her eyes is of child-like awe. She’s arrived!
A BELL RINGS as Agnes enters the cluttered shop. A HEAVIL PIERCED YOUNG MAN at the counter looks up from his phone.
Let me know if you need any help. The place is a puzzle-lover's fantasy come to life; dusty dark, almost like an old bookstore, with wall-to-wall puz of every type imaginable.
The Young Man watches Agnes, her arms full of puzzles, agonizing between two final purchases.
You ready?
What do you think, sir? Which one? (CONTINUED )
She holds up the two puzzles: a portrait of a mother bath her child (Mary Cassatt’s painting "Mother and Child") an painting of naked woman lying provocatively on a couch (Goya's "The Nude Maja").
Uh... depends on what you want to spend days looking at.
What do you mean?
They're each a thousand pieces. They take forever. Agnes looks at them.

I'll take both. She carries her pile of puzzles to the counter. The Young starts RINGING her up. Agnes focuses on a handwritten sign with tiny tabs hangin off the bottom on a bulletin board nearby: “CHAMPION DESPERATELY LOOKING FOR PUZZLE PARTNER”. She gazes at the sign for a while, then looks away and finds her wallet, b then her eyes land on the sign again. AGNES (CONT’D) (pointing to sign) What’s that about? “Desperately”. The Young Man turns to look at the sign.
I don’t know. Some guy. My father is usually here. I’m just visiting.
Is he sick?
Who?
Your dad.
No. He just had a meeting out of town.
Good. Please take good care of him. It’s devastating when they’re gone, believe me. (CONTINUED )
60 61 62 63 64 65 66 CONTINUED: (2) 27. 60 The Young Man stares at her, confused.
He’ll be back tomorrow.

Carrying two bags of puzzles, Agnes steps out of the stor onto the sun-drenched sidewalk. She breathes the day in. turns around and steps back inside. We see her through the window, pointing at the sign on th bulletin board and talking with the Young Man.

The sun sets over New York City as Agnes's train speeds n back to Bridgeport. Agnes sits near a knocked-out loaded SNORING MAN IN A SUI She's holding one of the little paper tabs from the Puzzlemania bulletin board in her hand, staring. It reads Text 646-977-7839.
Agnes lies awake in bed; Louie is asleep next to her. SNORING.
Agnes tiptoes into the kitchen in her nightgown with her iPhone in her hand and the Mary Cassatt’s "Mother and Chi puzzle box. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 65
Agnes puts puzzle pieces together with speed and efficien She’s a natural. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 66

"Mother and Child" completed, Agnes gets up, moves to the other side of the table, puts the phone on the table and next to it, as if it was a typewriter. Using one finger, she touches the MESSAGES icon. Giddily, gets into text mode. She looks at the screen, unsure, the touches the WRITE icon. Then balks. (CONTINUED )

Types the phone number off the paper tab she fishes out o her nightgown pocket. Then deletes it. Then she types it again and writes: “Hi. My name is Agnes. I think I might be good at this.” After a pause she types: “Puzzles, I mean.” Then, on an impulse, she presses "SEND" and closes her ey A beat later, a response text RINGS and she opens her eye surprise. The text reads: “How good?” She giggles and sta to type back with one finger.
Agnes lies awake in bed next to Louie. She’s holding her phone to heart. Can’t sleep. Louie’s SNORING doesn’t help
Agnes kneels before FATHER KUTASH, a line of people waiti behind her. Kutash dips his thumb into some ashes and mak a small cross on Agnes's forehead. It’s Ash Wednesday.
Remember that thou art dust and to dust thou shalt return...
Agnes expertly hands her ticket to ANOTHER TRAIN CONDUCTO and watches while he punches it. He also has an Ash Cross his forehead, peeking from underneath his uniform hat. Sh likes that.
Thank you.
Agnes walks down a cobblestoned street, counting numbers under her breath.

Agnes is standing in front of a beautiful but slickly contemporary townhouse. She walks up the steps. Peers into the security camera. L her finger to ring the buzzer, but before she even touche the door opens. Standing in front of her is ROBERT. Handsome, in his 50s, wearing simple but not inexpensive clothes. THE WEATHER CHANNEL IS ON TV INSIDE THE HOUSE. (CONTINUED )
I'm Agnes. Hi! Agnes sticks her hand out. He shakes it.

Robert. Come in. You write funny texts, Agnes. 29. 71 Agnes smiles politely and enters the house where she take off her jacket. He follows her in and closes the door beh him INT. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE. WEST VILLAGE - CONTINUOUS They stand awkwardly at the entrance.
Have you seen the news?
What? No. I-- I’m-- I'm here about the puzzles.

The flood in India. Thousands of people washed away just like that. Boggles the mind. There was an earthquake in Northern Iran. I’m not trying to be gloomy. I know we're just meeting. It’s just-- Too much!
Oh. I-- I didn’t hear-- She laughs nervously, then stops herself. AGNES (CONT’D) How are my texts funny?
What? Oh-- I'm sorry, but... you seem to have some dirt on your forehead.
Oh. I- He reaches out to brush it off.
It's Ash Wednesday. He pulls back.
Oh, is that today?
(CONTINUED )
All day.
You're Catholic?
Is that a problem? He smiles, she’s strange.
Not at all. As long as we don’t have to share the prize with the pope. Agnes stays put, a bit stunned.
What prize? INT. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE. WEST VILLAGE - DAY Agnes nervously follows Robert to a coat closet...
You said “prize”.
Every competition has a prize. INT. LIVING ROOM. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - CONTINUOUS
Robert hangs her coat in the coat closet...
Your ad didn’t mention a prize. Robert keeps walking and Agnes follows him... INT. LIVING ROOM. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - CONTINUOUS 74-
They move through a living room with a huge table and chandelier...
I thought it was obvious. “CHAMPION
PARTNER”. Did you think I was looking for companionship?
No. No. Of course not. Just-- a partner. 72 73 75 (CONTINUED )
For a competition. AGNES . . . I’ve never competed in anything in my life.
Not even for the affection of your husband?
What? I-- How do you know I’m married? She realizes the ring on her finger.
Educated guess.
I could be a widow.
Are you?

Sometimes. He laughs. 76 INT. DEN. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - CONTINUOUS 76 ..-And into the perfectly-organized den/study at the back the house where a TV is on, tuned to the Weather Channel. Large magnets, plastic tubings and blueprints are piled u the desk and wall, untouched, like a museum piece. Robert opens a small door and holds it for Agnes.
May I ask-- Why did you answer the ad? She shrugs, then looks away, embarrassed, about to say something.
Oh, no, don’t say it?
What?
I thought you were going to say you were... “puzzled by the ad.” (CONTINUED )
She smiles uncomfortably.
And don’t think your smiling right now worries me any less. INT. LIBRARY. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - DAY 77

Agnes and Robert enter a beautiful mahogany puzzle suite, filled with reading lamps and lined with bookshelves and ladders leading to higher shelves, all filled with puzzle The adjoining area is a circular room where an oak table two leather chairs await the players.
Sit. Please. Agnes sits down at the table. Still stunned. Robert perus one of his bookshelves, pulls a puzzle out and dumps the pieces out in front of Agnes.
All right. Let's see how we work together.
(anxious ) Is this a test?
Absolutely.
What’s the competition?

National Jigsaw Puzzle championship. Single competition is five-hundred piece puzzles. The doubles is a thousand pieces. It’s limited to a hundred and eighty couples. I won the singles last year. My first time.
I didn’t know such a thing existed.
Don’t tell anyone. There’1ll be a run on the place.
What happened to your partner?
How do you know I had a partner? (CONTINUED )
You wouldn't sign up for doubles if you didn’t have a partner.
Very good. She left.
Why? He takes her in.

Show me how you do puzzles, then maybe I‘1l tell you. Agnes nervously starts gathering pieces and looking at th She then grabs handfuls of pieces and begins spreading th out. ROBERT (CONT’D You're not doing colors first? Agnes shakes her head.
Rule number one of competitive puzzling. You've got to organize by color before you do anything else. Agnes nods meekly and starts organizing by color.

I'll do green and the oranges. You do the red and the dark browns. They are silent for a minute as they work. Then Agnes rea for the cover to turn it and look at it for a long time. Robert sighs and pushes his chair back.
How long have you been puzzling?
A while.
How long is awhile?
I’m very fast.
You said that in your text. How long? (CONTINUED )

I can’t remember. Years. I was always good in math. Patterns. Shapes. I just picked a puzzle up the other day and-- there it was, like riding a bike. Agnes averts her gaze. She’s lying. He takes her in. INT. LIBRARY. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - LATER 78

Agnes and Robert are working together in silence. They're about a third of the way through the puzzle. Robert pause watch Agnes. Her hands move rapidly; she seems to sense t a piece won't fit even before trying it. Robert raises his eyebrows, then reaches for a piece. Agn reaches for it at the same time. Their hands bump.
Sorry. Pardon me. INT. LIBRARY. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE — LATER 79 There's only one puzzle piece left on the table. They bot stare at it hungrily, like it's the last remaining bite o cake.
Go ahead. Agnes picks up the piece and gleefully fits it in to comp the puzzle. She laughs out of sheer delight. Robert turns and looks at the timer. It reads 48 minutes 26 seconds.
Fuck me! She looks at him uncomfortably.
Pardon my French. She laughs.
You don’t get out much, do you? She shakes her head.
And yet you came to a total stranger's door and willingly followed him in. (CONTINUED )
She nods.
May I ask. Again. Respectfully. Why? She shrugs. Then laughs to herself.
You were just tempted to say it again, weren’t you? She nods.
Go ahead. Get it out of your system. She shakes her head.
It’s inevitable. Get out of jail free. Say it once and never again.
Your ad said “desperately”. I was... puzzled. She cracks herself up, roaring with laughter. He looks at with strange fascination. Something’s off with her, somet fascinating to him.
Agnes puts her jacket on by the coat closet.
Are you sure you don't need to think about it?
Not for a minute. You’re a godsend. This was meant to be. Agnes tries hard to contain her smile.
What works for you? We need to meet at least twice a week. The tournament is in a month. That's barely enough time to prepare.
Oh. (CONTINUED )
Don't tell me you can't do it now.

No. I can do it. (forcefully) I'll do it. I want to. I’1l-- Yes. Wait-- He stares at her, intrigued. She’s looking away, as if do calculations in her mind. AGNES (CONT’D) Why did she leave you, your partner?
She just left. No explanation, really. Just up and gone. Not even a note.
So she wasn’t just a puzzle partner?
No. She was my wife.
Was she good? At puzzles, I mean.
Better than most. Not as good as you. She smiles to herself.
Okay. Mondays and Wednesdays. te herself) Mondays and Wednesdays. (to Robert) You don’t have to be at work?
I work at home.
Oh, yeah? Me too.
Agnes, Louie and the boys are in the middle of dinner.
(nervously) ...I got some bad news. They all stop and look at her. (CONTINUED )
Aunt Emily is sick. I mean, she broke her foot, the poor thing.
How?
She tripped.
That's too bad.
So I'll be going to New Rochelle two days a week to help her out. You know, buy groceries, cook some meals for her... Mondays and Wednesdays. For about a month.
That's a long time, Agnes.
You won't even notice the difference.
Should we go visit her too? AGNES GABE | ; I don't think that's I've got a lot going on this necessary. weekend.
Should I write her a card? Agnes pats Ziggy's hand.
Yes. That's a nice idea. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 82
Through the kitchen door we see Ziggy smoking in the back and browsing through his phone. Agnes is cleaning up. She hums to herself. Gabe is on his laptop at the kitchen tab
(staring at the laptop) It says I have to write one essay about "why I want to go to college" and in another essay I have to describe a"transformative experience" in my life.
What does that mean? (CONTINUED )
They all ask for it. UConn, all the SUNY schools..."why do you want to go to college?""Describe a transformative experience in your life."
THE DOORBELL RINGS and Gabe jumps up. INT. LIVING ROOM/DEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 83

Agnes has her feet soaking in a tub of warm water in the living room. Louie is meticulously handcrafting pieces of fishing lure. Nicki and Gabe are splayed out on the den floor looking a Gabe’s laptop. Next to them, Ziggy is watching a “Big Brother” type show on television.
What about the time we went to Hungary with Grandpa?
That was me, mom. I wasn’t there mom. That was Ziggy. IT GETS QUIET FOR A LONG BEAT SAVE FOR THE REALITY SHOW.

What about the time I got sick after my father died? That was hard on all of you. They all freeze. The SOUND OF THE TV DOMINATES FOR A BEAT Nicki stares, unsure what to say. Louie pretends he isn’t listening.
Okay, I got it. When that ugly girl popped your cherry. That must have been transformative. You haven’t made sense ever since. Gabe throws a pillow at Ziggy, but misses and hits Louie.
Fuck you!
Hey! Hey! Goddamnit. There’s a lady present.
(to Nicki) I apologize. (CONTINUED )
That’s okay. A long pause.
I’m here too, Gabe. I’m a lady present.
What? Oh. Sure. Sorry, Mom.
Thank you.
I meant we had a guest, Agnes.
I know.
Let's face it, there’s just nothing transformative in my life. Maybe I shouldn’t even go to college.
That’s not a conversation for right now.
You have to go to college.
Whatever. Louie shakes his head and goes back to his fly-fishing ba

(to herself) “Transformative” is such a funny word. Trans. Form. A. Tive. Trans. For. Mat. Ive. Trans. Format... Agnes looks up at the TV and splashes her feet in the wat making a little rhythm out of the splashing. Ziggy watche her, amused.
Why are you in such a good mood all of a sudden, Mom? Agnes looks self-conscious for a second, caught. Then she smiles and splashes her feet a little more. (CONTINUED )
I’m just happy we’re all together here. Right now. Like this. 40. 83 Nicki looks at her. You can see a hurt, un-parented child of a sudden. No.
Can I sleep over tonight? On the couch.
Well--
On the couch.
What about your parents?
They’re out of town. I feel safer here.
I could go sleep over at her place.
No. Louie and Agnes exchange looks. Ziggy laughs. AGNES (CONT’D) I’ll get the extra blanket. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - LATER

head_text.subj: MUSIC BLASTING UPSTAIRS SEEPS THROUGH THE CEILING.

text: Agnes are putting dishes away.
She's using you. Everyone always uses you and you let them. You’re a sucker is what you are.
It’s called being kind.
Sucker is being kind with no filter.
She’s my aunt.
She has her own family. You have things to do here. We need you. (MORE)
84 Louie and (CONTINUED )
I need you. I got those invoices piling up at the garage you could help with. And, anyway, you need rest. You can’t go.
I’ve rested enough. Why do you always do this?

I’m just worried about you. The doctor said-- (changing approach) Maybe I’m selfish. Okay? I admit it. I love you too much. You take such good care of us. And I want you to take it easy, is that so wrong? Let me call her.
No. I-- I-- I’1l call her and let her know I can’t come twice a week.
Not even once a week. For your sake, Agnes.
Okay. He kisses her on the cheek and leaves; he’s done helping, point made
Louie is SNORING AGAIN. Agnes lies awake, listening to hi After a second, she jabs him, with her elbow. He jumps.
Wha-? Huh?
You're snoring.
What do you want me to do about it?
Stop.
How?
I don’t know. (CONTINUED )
Louie moans and turns over on his side.
Relax. It’s late. Go to sleep. And then he goes back to sleep quietly.

head_text.subj: THE SOUNDS OF GABE AND NICKI HAVING SEX SUDDENLY BUILDS U

text: Oh, God. Agnes buries herself under the covers. Louie starts SNORI AGNES (CONT’ D) (whispering td herself) I knew she wouldn’t stay on the couch.
Agnes waits on the platform as The Metro North train ROAR into the station and comes to a full stop.
Agnes hurries through the Grand Central atrium.

Agnes sits in a crowded subway car, nervous. A BLIND MAN stands close by, SINGING "AVE MARIA" IN AN ALMOST IMPOSSI HIGH VOICE. Agnes gets up and gives The Blind Man a dollar. EXT. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE. PERRY STREET. WEST VILLAGE - DAY

Agnes nervously approaches Robert's townhouse and stops c spotting: An impatient MAN IN A SUIT RINGING ROBERT’S DOORBELL. Agnes watches him try the bell a few more times, BANG ON DOOR, then give up and walk off angry. She remains frozen in place. (CONTINUED )
Then slowly Robert’s door opens. He stands there smiling motions for her to come in.
Robert leads Agnes toward the den/study. MID-CONVERSATION
...-I don’t open the door for the past.
I’m not sure I understand.

That man was a business associate of mine. I don’t have any patience for business these days. Too much pressure. And anyway, I was watching the surveillance camera footage online from the mass shooting last night. Have you seen it? It’s so goddamn awful. He stops and faces her. She lowers her eyes.
I don’t have as much time as I thought. I’m sorry. We better start. INT. LIBRARY. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - DAY 92
Robert dramatically dumps an entire 1000-piece puzzle out onto the table.
So they give you the puzzle and you pour the whole thing out at once. You don't take little handfuls and spread them around the table. I noticed you doing that the other day. Agnes nods, seated.
You also stand up. She stands up.
Then you walk around the table a couple of times before you start. (CONTINUED )
They both walk around the table a couple of times, it’s awkward. She giggles.
You get more perspective this way. You see puzzle pieces without the glare. You see patterns you might not have seen from your Chair. Different color schemes. Agnes nods, still circling the table.
All right. Now we can sit. They sit. Robert hits the timer.

It's faster to divide things up. So I'll do borders, you do colors. INT. LIBRARY. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - DAY 93 Agnes and Robert are about halfway through the puzzle. Sh moving with great speed, fitting pieces into the puzzle f while sneaking peeks at the timer.
Your name should actually be pronounced "Ag-NESH," right? She looks up, surprised.
That's how my father would pronounce it, yes. But I was born here.
Ag-nesh Oros.
I was Mata before Oros. That’s my maiden name. Agnes Mata.
Really? Bet you’ve heard plenty of Mata Hari jokes growing up.
Not even one. She goes back to the puzzle again. Robert stops the timer then leans over and presses the intercom buzzer on the wa (CONTINUED )
Tea, Maria. Agnes looks at him surprised. Then laughs.
What’s funny?
A blind man on the train was singing “Ave Maria”.
And that’s funny how?
“Tea, Maria.” “Ave Maria”. I don’t know. It’s ironic.
That’s not irony. That's coincidence. It doesn’t mean anything. AGNES ; It must mean something.
You don’t really believe that. Do you? He gets up.
Come. She follows as they walk into: INT. TEA ROOM. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - CONTINUOUS A94
They sit just as MARIA, a young, pretty maid, comes in wi teetering tray full of teacups and cookies. Agnes immedia leaps up to help her.

I'm fine, ma'am, thank you. She's fine. Agnes sits down and watches as Maria sets the cups down, pours the tea, etc. She keeps reaching out to help her, t steady things. Robert watches Agnes. When Maria leaves, Robert leans back in his chair, balanc his tea cup on his knee. Agnes takes a sip of the tea.
You like it? Agnes nods, suddenly uneasy. She bites into a cookie. IT CRUNCHES LOUDLY. (CONTINUED )
You're so much more comfortable when you're focusing on the puzzle, aren't you? Agnes nods.
Why?
You ask a lot of questions.
That's how you get to know someone.
But I don’t ask you anything.
Go ahead. She looks away, as if calculating.
I can’t think of a question right now.
That’s my point. You’re uncomfortable around me.

Well, I don’t know you... But it’s not just you. I don’t feel comfortable, generally, because I-- She's thinking. He watches her patiently. AGNES (CONT’D) --Because normally my mind is-- I-- I don’t know.

Because normally your mind is moving so fast, you don’t really know where it’s going. There’s nowhere for you to express your mind. No one to express it to. It makes you nervous. So you shut down and focus on menial tasks. Puzzles are menial tasks for you, so you can focus. But the results are aesthetically pleasing and you like it. It turns you on. She stares at him. (CONTINUED )
Ag4 CONTINUED: (2) 47. aA94
Impressed?
I’m not sure I totally understand what you just said. He laughs.
Honestly, Agnes, if you learn the rules and hone your technique, I think we have a good chance at going to Belgium. I’m not kidding here.
(shocked) Belgium?
The WJPF international competition. It’s in Brussels. Right after the nationals. Ever been? Agnes shakes her head, clearly anxious.
All I’m saying is that if we win the nationals we go on to the World Jigsaw Puzzle Federation competition. The color drains out of Agnes's face.
You don't want a free trip to the ancestral home of the Brussel sprout, Mata? Agnes shakes her head and tries to smile.
We don’t have time for tea. He looks at her as she gets up and returns to the puzzle table.
(singing softly) Ave maria, gratia plena, Dominus tecum. She laughs. (CONTINUED )
Ag4 94 95 96 97 CONTINUED: (3) 48.
(singing) Benedicta tu in mulieribus, et benedictus fructus ventris tui, Iesus...

Agnes hurries to the subway, passing the window of a gour chocolate shop. Suddenly, she slows her steps. Stops. And turns around. She studies her reflection in the window, becoming self-conscious. Moves her hair back. Switches he bag over to the other side. Stands straight. She suddenly notices a MAN MUNCHING ON A CHOCOLATE BAR looking at her from inside the store through the glass. S turns her back to him.

Eating chocolate, Agnes rides the train back home, one br dress in a sea of commuter suits. She checks her watch. Shakes her head to herself. Then gets her iPhone out. Bro through it tentatively. Turns to the BUSINESSMAN sitting to her.
Excuse me. Can you show me how Google works?
Agnes is typing on her phone. We see a Google entry: “Mat Hari”.

location: LOUIE K'S AUTOBODY AND REPAIR. BRIDGEPORT, CT

text: Auto body sanding and grinding is going on. We're in a small, somewhat rundown garage located on the outskirts of Bridgeport. An old sign reads: "Louie K's." Agnes's car pulls into the garage. She gets out. Louie emerges, smudged with grease.
Look who it is! He gives her a hug and a kiss.
To what do we owe the honor? (CONTINUED )
She holds out a box of chocolates.
What, are you trying to kill me?
No. God. It’s just-- You've been so good.
I was kidding, Agnes. Louie takes the chocolate with his grubby hands and kisse her.
I thought maybe I’1l take a look at those invoices.
Ziggy emerges.
Oh. Hey, Mom.
Where were you?
Bathroom.
You were coming from outside.
I was takin' a smoke break.
So why'd you just say you were in the bathroom?
That’s were I was before. You don’t want me to smoke in the bathroom, do you? The two men look at each other.
I’m gonna get started.

location: BACK ROOM. LOUIE K'S AUTOBODY AND REPAIR

text: A small glass window looks out onto the activity in the garage below. Sitting at a messy desk, Agnes stuffs a pile of invoices (CONTINUED )

an envelope, scrawls something on it, then sets it aside. picks up another piece of paper, starts to put it aside, frowns and inspect it. She shakes her head to herself, looking very worried all of a sudden. Then she stands up and looks out the glass window. Louie talking to a YOUNG WOMAN who is picking up her car. She's nodding and thanking him. Then Louie cracks a joke and sh laughs.
I don’t understand how you can stay married to him for so long. Agnes turns around. Ziggy is there, his hands stuffed in pockets.
Oh. You scared me.
Sorry.
Your father is a decent, good man.
Yeah. That’s what he says about you. Seriously. All the other guys flirt with the customers and he just like talks about how awesome his wife is all the time.
That's nice. They look at each other.
Are you okay, Zig?
Ah...I don't know. (pause) I’m miserable. I hate my life.
Oh, honey.
Dad hired me out of pity. And now it's been nine months.
That’s not true. Ziggy sighs. (CONTINUED )
98 CONTINUED: (2) 51. 98
I'm not good at this. Do you know what it's like to spend all day not doing the thing you're good at? Agnes doesn't answer. They look at each other.
So what would you rather do? What are you good at?
I don't think I’m good at anything. Agnes sighs and hugs Ziggy. He’s fighting tears.
What happened to you, Mom?
Nothing. I just got lost, honey, when Grandpa died-- He was-- You know, it was just my dad and me for so Many years. I was confused. I needed a place to rest.
You've only had men in your life.
I guess that’s true. He wipes his tears.
Can't be much of a man if I’m crying.
Oh, Ziggy, honey, men cry! They cry more than women. But not always with tears. It’s okay.
I want to cook, Mom.
What?
You asked me what I’m good at, I don’t know. But I want to cook.
Seriously? (CONTINUED )
Yes. I’ve watched you cook all my life. I watch cooking shows when no one’s home. I think I’d be happy doing what you do, not what Dad does.
But I don’t do anything.
Are you fucking kidding me? You do a million things. And you're good at all of them. She smiles, pleased.
Can I ask you for a favor?
Sure.
Can you show me how to work the apps on my phone?
Yeah.
But don’t tell Gabe.

HIP HOP MUSIC PLAYS LOUDLY as EIGHT SEVENTEEN-YEAR OLDS, including Gabe and Nicki, are hanging out, some deep into XBox, some chatting, laughing, looking through a photo bo posing for iPhones snaps, drinking soda, etc.. Agnes enters from the kitchen and lays down snacks on the table.
Thanks, Mrs. Oros.
Does anyone need anything? No reply. She looks at Gabe. He’s busy. AGNES (CONT’D) (a bit too loud) Does anyone need anything? (CONTINUED )
100 101 102 CONTINUED: 53. Everyone stares at her. She smiles to herself. 100 __ AGNES (CONT’D) I guess it’s just me.
Agnes and Louie are brushing their teeth together, side b side, looking in the mirror at their reflections.
I feel bad that Ziggy never got to go to college. LOUIE ; He got terrible grades. Gabe is the smart one.
But still. Maybe he should've tried. Or we should've helped him try.
We didn't have the money.
Do you ever wish you'd gone? To college, I mean? Learn things just to know them?
Nope. I would've hated it. Agnes nods and spits out her toothpaste.
I think I would have majored in math.
Math, huh? That’s cute.
Ever wonder what your life would be like if you met me a few years later. Or never met me at all?
Not for one second. I thank God I have you every day.
Every single day? (CONTINUED )
And night. He chuckles and kisses her cheek. AGNES. I think we should watch the news.
Now?
No. Just more often.
Why? Nothing good’s happening in the world.
Still. Shouldn’t we know about it? He shrugs. She rinses off her toothbrush, and then heads of the bathroom, shutting off the light as she goes.
(in the darkness) Hey! Agnes! I’m still here.
Sorry.
The door opens and Robert smiles at her. He’s in his coat Agnes is taken aback as he steps out and closes the door behind him.
Are you going somewhere?
No. WE are.
(alarmed) Together? Where?
It’s a surprise. He takes her hand but she recoils.
I don’t like surprises.
You’1l like this one.  104 55.

Agnes and Robert are sitting across from each other at a table, working on a new puzzle, the timer running. Agnes very tense and ill at ease. We move back to see the store basement lined with shelves stacked with puzzles and filled with populated tables: a collection of ODD BALLS, mostly elderly folks, all gather to puzzle together. Agnes moves uncomfortably in her seat. She’s not her usua fluid puzzler, she can’t focus. AGNES AND ROBERT WHISPER

head_text.subj: WHILE PUZZLING FOR THE REST OF THE SCENE

text: I don’t understand why we have to compete already?
What’s the big deal? Agnes shakes her head, she’s upset.
Who are these people?
I thought we'd do this to boost your confidence.
Well, you thought wrong.
Just focus on what I’m doing. She looks around, catches some glimpses. Gets back to the puzzle.
I looked you up. I mean, I googled you. On my phone.
Oh?
You’re an inventor.
